In Julia, Write a function `clean_column` that cleans a column name (`col`) by lowercasing it, stripping any leading or trailing whitespaces, and replacing any spaces and hyphens with an underscore, eg, "My Column" becomes "my_column".

In Julia, you can define a function `clean_column` that performs these operations on a column name. The function should take a string `col` as input and return the cleaned version of the column name. Here's how you can implement it:

```julia
function clean_column(col)
    # Lowercase the string
    col = lowercase(col)
    
    # Strip leading and trailing whitespaces
    col = strip(col)
    
    # Replace spaces and hyphens with underscores
    col = replace(col, " " => "_")
    col = replace(col, "-" => "_")
    
    return col
end
```

This function first lowercases the input string. Then it strips any leading or trailing whitespaces. Finally, it replaces all spaces and hyphens with underscores.

You can use this function as follows:

```julia
julia> clean_column("My Column")
"my_column"

julia> clean_column("my column")
"my_column"

julia> clean_column("my-column")
"my_column"
```

The function is flexible enough to handle various input formats and ensures that the output is in a consistent lowercase with underscores instead of spaces or hyphens.
